etymologies: early 19th century; earliest use found in Henry James Brooke (1771–1857), crystallographer. From French websterite from the name of Thomas Webster, Scottish geologist + French -ite

definitions: A whitish mineral consisting of a hydrated basic sulphate of aluminium, typically occurring in opaque, clay-like masses.

etymologies: late 19th century. From Webster, the name of a village in North Carolina, where the mineral was originally discovered + -ite

definitions: An ultramafic, ultrabasic rock formed in the cavities and fissures of other rocks and composed of approximately equal amounts of orthopyroxene and clinopyroxene, typically having a greyish, banded appearance.
